(Tribute)

3.24 pm

     The Leader of the House (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I, on behalf of all Members of this House, extend to you our congratulations on your re-election as Speaker. You are not new to this high office, having been first elected to it three days short of three years ago in 1989. Your re-election today signifies our continued confidence in you in the discharge of this onerous responsibility.

Column: 10



    During the Seventh Parliament you have guided our proceedings most efficiently and ensured that order and decorum were observed in keeping with the dignity of this House. You have acted fairly and firmly to all Members regardless of whether he was a Minister, a Government Backbencher or an Opposition Member. You have ensured that Members did not stray from the agenda under discussion and that you did not hesitate to bring an errant Member back to his correct path. I am sure all the Members here will continue to give you our support and cooperation in the years ahead.

    I would also like to take this opportunity to thank Mr Lim Boon Heng who has contributed to the proceedings of this House as our Deputy Speaker. He now has other responsibilities and he will no doubt be taking part in the proceedings of this House in his new assignment as Senior Minister of State.

    We are also privileged to have the continued services of Mr Abdullah Tarmugi as our Deputy Speaker when he is duly re-elected.

    On behalf of the older Members, I would like to welcome the 14 new Members into this House. We look forward to their maiden speeches and to their participation in the debate.

    Parliamentary debate is serious business. What matters is the substance of what Members say, not how they can impress the viewers in the "Today in Parliament" programme. The Government is more interested in what Members say in helping to improve any aspect of its policies. We want to hear the constructive comments on how certain things can be done better. I can assure them that constructive views would be well received. We want to hear alternatives if they disagree with the present policies. But if their views are plainly wrong, they

Column: 11

must expect a strong encounter from the Government.

    Under the Parliament (Privileges, Immunities and Powers) Act, Members are free to speak their minds. But let me remind them that they shall have to take responsibility for what they say.

    We have had a clean record in the Seventh Parliament when no Member was taken before the Committee of Privileges. I hope Members will keep this record up and not require the Committee of Privileges to meet in the Eighth Parliament.

    One final point, Sir. We now have four Opposition Members in this House, three of whom are from the same party, the SDP. For informal communication between me, as Leader of the House, and the Opposition, I propose to deal with Mr Chiam as the unofficial Leader of the Opposition. It is like the position in the Legislative Assembly in 1955 when the PAP won three out of four contested seats in the Legislative Assembly, and Mr Lee Kuan Yew was unofficially and de facto Leader of the Opposition. As its unofficial Opposition Leader, this House should give Mr Chiam due courtesy and precedence among Opposition MPs.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am happy to note that you have been unanimously re-elected as Speaker of this House.

    Sir, allow me and my two colleagues to join the Leader of the House and also, I believe, other Members of the House, in congratulating you on your re-election to this high office.

    Sir, I was fortunate to be a Member of this House in the last session of Parliament when you were also a Speaker. You are a very patient man and often your patience has been tested and you were never

Column: 12

ruffled. I note also that you have got a good sense of humour which is most welcome in long and tedious sessions. Sir, I am confident that you will perform your duties impartially and fairly.

    I am fortunate to be sitting in front and it is easy for me to catch your eye. But my other two colleagues have been placed at the back seats. I hope they can also catch your eye.

    Sir, I welcome the recognition of me as the unofficial Leader of the Opposition. You can be assured, Sir, that I will certainly live up to a Leader of the Opposition, whether officially or unofficially. I think it is the duty, the way that I perform in Parliament and the keeping of my responsibility which are more important than a name which is attached to me.

    Sir, you can be assured that the SDP Members will definitely be constructive. We are all here with a mission in nation-building and we shall certainly keep our record of nation-building and we hope for Singapore's further progress.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Bedok GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I join my colleagues in congratulating you on your re-election as Speaker of Parliament. Since your election as Speaker in 1989, you have guided this House fairly and with wit and wisdom. Your eyes are sharp and your timing very sharp. I am sure that under your leadership and shining example, this House will indeed benefit from your chairmanship.

    I would also like to congratulate Mr Chiam See Tong on being appointed the unofficial Leader of the Opposition in this House.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Mr Speaker, I rise to support your nomination and to congratulate you on being re-elected as Speaker.

Column: 13



    For the new Members of Parliament in this House, I can assure them that the Speaker, who now has little time to speak and, in fact, he cannot speak much in this House, did a very fine job when he was a Backbencher. We looked towards him when we were new in this House for guidance and if you go back and look through the Hansard, you will find that some of his speeches were very witty and humorous. And I am sure the Front Bench in this House were at times disturbed by some of the remarks that he made. We, on the Backbench, although we miss him, are also proud that he has been elevated to the Chair of Speaker. Congratulations.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to join the Leader of the House and the other Members to congratulate you on your re-election as the Speaker of this House for another term.

    Sir, you have a very long experience as a Backbencher in the past years and you know that the Backbenchers have a responsibility to reflect the views of the members of the public and their electorate. Therefore, from my own experience over the past few years and in cooperating with you, I am quite sure that in the new session you will also give us a lot of opportunities to reflect our views. I also believe that you will be discharging your duties very fairly and impartially irrespective of whether he is a Government Backbencher or an Opposition Member. You will give every one of them equal opportunity to speak. And if a Member does not wish to speak, that is his own responsibility.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I hope and I believe that in the new session you will continue to be fair in maintaining the dignity, order and proper proceedings of this House, and that you will also help to conduct the substantial debate in this House.

Column: 14



     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I sincerely congratulate you on being elected as Speaker of the Eighth Parliament. I understand that you have been very fair at the last Parliament and I hope that you will be as fair as you have been and will not close ranks with PAP Members, as our Prime Minister has urged.

     Mr Speaker: Honourable Members, first of all, I would like to thank all of you for having elected me Speaker of the Eighth Parliament. I would also like to thank the Leader of the House and the other Members for their kind and supportive words.

    The Speakership is an office of high esteem and responsibility and it is an honour that you once again bestow on me by re-electing me to the Chair. That I was able to discharge my duties fully and responsibly in the Seventh Parliament is due in no small way to the cooperation which honourable Members extended to me.

    Together, we have shown to our people that even as we argue and debate, scrutinize and criticize, probe and query, we do so in an orderly manner that befits the honour and dignity of this distinguished House. This is the way it must be, always, so that our people continue to have faith in us. I therefore look forward to the continued cooperation of honourable Members in this new Parliament.

    All of us are bound by the Standing Orders, a set of rules that might appear cumbersome at times, but has passed the test of time in ensuring the orderly conduct of our proceedings. I would advise all Members to be familiar with them.

    Be free to speak your minds and let your conscience be your guide, but remember that at all times we should never abuse the privileges accorded to us as Members of Parliament. To do so would be to undermine the confidence that our

Column: 15

people have placed in this high institution. I therefore urge each and every one of you to uphold the rules, dignity and decorum of the House.

    Lastly, I would like to extend a warm welcome to the new Members. There are 14 of them and I look forward to hearing their speeches. A piece of friendly advice to them. Remember that not all of us are born orators and a good speech is not necessarily a long speech. All of you have the right to speak but do follow my advice, otherwise you might not understand why you have difficulty catching the Speaker's eye! For sure it is not where you sit that counts.

    One of the Speaker's most potent weapon in this House is the "guillotine" which comes down on a Member who has exceeded the time permitted for making a speech. The "guillotine" when inflicted on you is sharp and swift, and I have noticed in the past the devastating effects it has had on a Member when it falls on him in mid-sentence. So time your speeches well as I will be regulating the proceedings of the House with clock-work precision, a field I am somewhat familiar with.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS



     The President (Mr Wee Kim Wee): Honourable Members:

    The Next Lap sets out what we want Singapore to be in the next generation. My 2Government will translate these long term goals into immediate programmes, so that Singaporeans will be better off by the end of this term of Parliament.

    Standards of living have risen rapidly in Singapore. Jobs have been plentiful. Nearly everyone owns his own home, complete with telephone and television. CPF and POSB savings have gone up. Standards of health care have risen. More students are making it through secondary schools, and into polytechnics and universities. All this has been achieved because sound government policies have created a framework for sustained growth, and enabled Singaporeans to progress and prosper.

    But we are only half way up to becoming a developed country. The

Column: 17

more difficult half remains ahead of us. We can only get there as one united nation. Singaporeans naturally compete to do well individually and get ahead. But we must also work together to succeed as a group, and to strengthen the bonds among us. We must encourage the more able to do their best for themselves and for Singapore. But the more able also need to show concern for the others and help them to catch up. We should level up to progress, not level down to stagnate.

    The Government will play an essential role. It will reward drive and enterprise, and give each Singaporean the incentive to excel. It will invest heavily in education and human resources, so that each one can acquire the right knowledge and skills, be self-reliant, and earn more. The Government will also help to build up the assets of Singaporeans by upgrading and increasing the value of their HDB homes. This will give every citizen a share of the wealth we have created together, and strengthen his stake in Singapore.

    However, while the Government will subsidise investments like education and infrastructure, it will not subsidise consumption expenditure. To do so is to undermine the traditional virtues of thrift, personal responsibility and the will to achieve, and to weaken our economy. The experience of other countries has proved this again and again.

Education

    Education is the foundation of competitiveness. It is not a one-off exercise, but a lifelong process, as we acquire new knowledge and skills to keep up with new technology and adapt to economic changes.

    School results have steadily improved as we raised teaching standards and refined the education system. Demand for higher education has increased. The Institute of Technical Education will be formed this year, to train not only fresh school leavers, but older workers who

Column: 18

want to upgrade their skills and their jobs. A fourth polytechnic will be set up this year. NUS and NTU have increased their intakes, and will expand further as more qualified students graduate from schools. The Singapore Open University will admit students starting this year, to give adults who missed out on a tertiary education a second chance to work for university degrees.

    Education is an investment in our people. We must invest more in our most promising students, while looking after the needs of the less able. In schools, we need to give parents a wider range of choices, so that their children can receive the education best tailored to their individual needs. This is the rationale for the independent schools and the Edusave scheme.

    We need to develop the independent schools into outstanding institutions, to give the most promising and able students an education matching their promise. Admission to these schools must be based principally on merit, not ability to pay. No bright child from a poor home need lose his chance to study in an independent school. There will be scholarships and bursaries for him. Attention paid to independent schools will not be at the expense of the other schools. Instead the other schools will benefit from ideas tested out successfully in the independent schools. By demonstrating what is possible, the independent schools will help other schools to raise standards.

    The Government will widen the Edusave scheme to achieve these objectives. It had previously announced that every year the scheme will contribute a sum to the Edusave account of each individual student. In addition, Edusave will now fund two types of scholarships. One scholarship will be for top pupils going to independent schools. They will be chosen based on academic merit, from among the best students in the country, regardless of family background. One quarter of the pupils in independent schools will receive such scholarships, which will cover the school fees.

Column: 19



    The second type of scholarship will be for students going to non-independent secondary schools. This scholarship can be awarded on a constituency or school basis, through grassroots organisations and school advisory or management committees. In this way good students in many schools, and not just the outstanding students in independent schools, will be recognised and encouraged to put in their best efforts.

    Besides awarding scholarships, Edusave will also make annual grants to government and government-aided secondary schools. The schools will have discretion to use these grants, for example to hire extra specialist staff, for additional equipment like computers, or for bursaries to help needy students. They can be equipped more like independent schools.

    To fund these new schemes, the annual Edusave contribution to individual accounts will be correspondingly reduced.

Housing

    Nearly every Singaporean now owns the home he lives in. The Government will refurbish and upgrade the older HDB estates, to approximate the quality of newer estates like Pasir Ris and Bis2han. Demonstration projects will be launched later this year. If they are popular with residents, HDB will upgrade other neighbourhoods which want to do so over the next 10 to 15 years. Meanwhile, we can make many improvements to existing estates, to spruce up common areas and improve essential facilities, for example by water-proofing bathroom floors. These investments will enhance the value of HDB homes, and increase the assets of Singaporeans.

    Many Singaporeans living in HDB flats wish to upgrade to private housing. Government will sell more land to private developers, for condominium and landed property developments.

Column: 20



    Besides homes, HDB has also built many shophouses, but so far it has only sold a few of them to the shopkeepers. As landlord, HDB has periodically needed to raise the rents of these shophouses, causing difficulties to some tenants. To solve this problem, HDB will sell most of these shophouses to the tenants. The price will be related to the market values of the properties, with an appropriate discount. This will enable the shop owners to plan ahead with certainty.

Health Care

    One area of concern to Singaporeans is health care. As incomes rise and the population ages, the demand for medical care will inevitably go up. As wages of medical staff go up, so will costs. So will national expenditure on health care. This has happened in every country.

    Singapore's per capita income is only half that of the US and Japan. Yet the subsidised wards of government hospitals already offer better medical care than most Japanese hospitals. Low income Singaporeans enjoy better medical care than many American families, who cannot afford medical insurance and have no access to good hospitals.

    The Government will ensure that all Singaporeans receive basic medical care. It will continue to subsidise B2 and C class wards, though it will still have to revise charges for these wards from time to time. There is a limit to the level of medical care which the Government can guarantee every citizen. The state cannot afford unlimited subsidies for high technology medicine, especially treatments which are recently discovered and not yet established. Every dollar spent on these areas is a dollar less for other proven, basic, and cost effective procedures. Patients who want non-standard treatments will have to pay for them at non-subsidised rates, or depend on the private sector.

    Governments which have provided free medical care for their citizens, like Canada, Britain, Spain, and other developed countries more affluent

Column: 21

than we are, all face serious difficulties. Sweden, after 70 years of state welfare, plans to reform its system of government funded free health care. Even Communist China intends to start charging government employees for medical care. No state can meet the insatiable demand for health care. The burden of the ever increasing expenditures ultimately falls back on the people.

    We must learn from these painful experiences of other countries. Our medical care system must create maximum incentive for responsibility, and minimumtemptation to waste. The individual has a personal responsibility to keep fit, stay healthy, minimise the need for medical treatment, and save for his own medical expenses.
